Dear DeLois Toins Leapheart:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/18/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1)Upon receipt of any information that relates to
possible noncompliance with any foster home rule, the
agency must do all the following:
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children
placed in the home that a spcial evlaution has been
initiated.
One of the two special evaluation reports reviewed did not document the worker
with children placed in the home was appropriately notified regarding the special
investigation as required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of the two special investigation reports reviewed included the last name of a
foster child placed in the home.
2

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
One of the two special investigation reports reviewed did not include adequate
documentation to confirm the foster parent was informed in writing that they could
have their written response included as an addendum to the completed
investigation/report. This information is normally included as a standard part of the
cover letter that is sent to the foster parent along with the report, but this letter could
not be located to determine compliance.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/12/2022, Renewal, CAP approved 10/27/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of the two special investigations reviewed required the completion of a
corrective action plan and there was no documentation the worker with children
placed in the home was given a copy of the corrective action plan to know what was
expected of the caregiver.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal evaluation completed
10/12/2022. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that review were Rules
324(4)(b)(d), 327(6)(b), 504(2)((f), 605(1), 607(2))c), 708(1), FOM 722-06B, and
FOM 722-03 C. The only area identified as a repeat noncompliance as a part of
this interim evaluation is Rule 327(6)(b).
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment included a review of the agency's corrective
action plan for the renewal evaluation completed 10/12/2022. The barriers to
establish and maintain compliance was also presented. The assessment
indicated a primary barrier continues to be the recruitment/retention of appropriate
staff to maintain the services provided by the agency. The assessment presented
additional tools being used by the agency to overcome this barrier.
Financial Overview
The financial audit completed by the appropriate third party for the time period
ending 12/31/2022 indicate the agency has appropriate finances and budget to
provide the required services to children and families.
Staff Interviews
Child welfare staff participated in entrance and exit conferences and no concerns
were identified/presented.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The walk through determined the record storage for the agency is in compliance
with licensing requirements for foster care, certification/licensing, and adoption
including CHRI.
4

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The analyst had one finding of a safety alert in a relative caregiver home and one
finding of a safety alert in a licensed foster home.
Concern #1: The concern in the relative home involved a need for door alarms due
to a potential water hazard outside and the need for a working smoke detector. T
Resolution: The issue was resolved with the installation of the needed
alarms/detectors and the emptying of the backyard pool. Picture documentation was
received 8/21/23 confirming compliance and approval was provided 9/6/2023.
Concern #2: The concern related to the foster home involved the use of breathable
bumper pads in a crib for a foster child with a medical condition.
Resolution: Medical documentation and variance approval was provided 8/10/2023
and approval was given 8/16/2023.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
